The grants gave to general-audi¬
ence etv the talents of scholars like
law professor Zechariah Chafee,
physicist Harold Urey, and seman-
ticist I. A. Richards.
A college professor who devotes
time and effort to etv often does so
at the expense of publication and
other traditional activities more
certain to move him up the aca¬
demic ladder. By 1959, etv stations
were more firmly established, and
faculty members throughout the
country were taking fuller advan¬
tage of educational programming.
Accordingly, the Foundation shift¬
ed the emphasis of the grants to
supporting college-faculty partici¬
pation in etv teaching for aca¬
demic credit.
